channel.description: SF Weekly: for news, music, arts, and events in San Francisco

item.title: "7 Boxes": The Things People Transport for Money
item.description: 7 Boxes Ambition and resourcefulness are of the essence in this zippy thriller from the Paraguayan filmmaking duo of Juan Carlos Maneglia and Tana Schémbori. The movie may lack the funds for elite-level production values, but it makes a vital and commanding bid for world-class statu...

item.title: "If You Build It": The Purpose of the Class Is to Build the Class
item.description: If You Build It Our first introduction to Emily Pilloton in Patrick Creadon's documentary If You Build It is in the context of a TED Talk she gave in 2010. Though she lays out the back-story for the film, If You Build It soon settles into a more traditional documentary struct...

item.title: Sizzle & Fizzle: Highs and Lows From Last the Week in S.F. Music
item.description:
Sizzle

We went behind the scenes at Red Bull Music Academy's Bass Camp, a weekend workshop in S.F. for promising producers. Electronic music legends like François K and Morton...

item.title: Bottomless Pit: Show Preview
item.description: Chicago quartet Bottomless Pit is the beautiful unsmiling creature that grew itself out of the ashes of the exemplary American indie-rock band Silkworm. The Pit is an agile and fitful beast, all ruminative gloom one moment and, well, anthemic gloom the next; its third LP, last year's Shade Per...

item.title: Mother Falcon: Show Preview
item.description: Logistics-wise, life as a touring band can't be too easy, since any successful group has to repeatedly accommodate the needs of multiple people at once. With 22 members — a number that constantly fluctuates based on need and availability — making Mother Falcon work must be a special k...

item.title: Madball: Show Preview
item.description: Get your wife-beaters on and your biceps flexing, Bay Area, because a legendary New York hardcore quartet is going to be tearing up Thee Parkside this Saturday — and in a venue this small, it's bound to be an explosive night. Madball is 25 years old now: a bona fide hardcore institution, a ...

item.title: Mark Mulcahy: Show Preview
item.description: Return with us now to the mid-1980s through the mid-'90s, when jangle-pop bands dotted the musical landscape: assorted combos with varying approaches but a common denominator of bright guitars and harmonious vocals. One such was Connecticut's Miracle Legion, initially dogged by comparisons to REM...

item.title: Re-Introductions: Two Artists Find New Uses for Satellite Photos and Old Books
item.description: Pop culture is visual culture. More people recognize Angelina Jolie than the opening lines of the Declaration of Independence ("When in the Course of human events, it becomes necessary..."). The average attention span can now focus for about eight seconds, so the demand for printed books continue...

item.title: Nelson Mandela Posters: 977 Mission St.
item.description: The posters show Nelson Mandela at his post-apartheid best: smiling, dignified, presidential. In mid-February, artist Robbie Conal and his cohorts pasted them up around Oakland, Berkeley, and San Francisco — part of an international effort by Conal and the South African nonprofit Art Aids A...

item.title: Singing the Climax: A New Musical Theater Company Launches with a Show About a Nymphomaniac's Lawsuit
item.description: In 2012, after conceiving the idea of creating a musical theater company telling only Bay Area stories, Tony Asaro was sitting at his computer searching for alluring, culturally relevant stories for the theater's first musical production. Gazing at the Google search bar, he typed: "san francisco ...

item.title: The Son of a Bitch Gets All the Best Lines: Rise of the Antihero
item.description: I worked in record stores for years, right before they began to be threatened by online pirating: The Golden Age of Record Stores. This was the late '90s and early aughts, the height of sarcasm and snark. Irony had gone mainstream, and we saw it on the T-shirts, trucker hats, and Ween albums of o...

item.title: My First Porno: Or, How I Learned to Stop Trusting "Loveline"
item.description: In the winter of 2009, I sat in my tiny bedroom in the Inner Richmond — a glorified laundry room with a linoleum floor and a futon mattress in the corner. I stared at my laptop screen. On it flashed the model application for The Crash Pad Series, an independent queer porn site based out of ...

item.title: The Esseffies 2014: Our Unexpected, Unnecessary Film Awards
item.description: Nothing in or around film underwhelms so completely as the Oscars. The hype is too great, the surprises too few. So, for a second year, we offer our own awards for cinematic merit with no hype and practically nothing you could guess in advance. Thus, for the Esseffies 2014, we hope to leave you c...

item.title: Mark Kozelek Misses Nothing: On Sun Kil Moon's Benji
item.description:
Mark Kozelek has a bad back, owns a $350 pair of lampshades, gets frustrated trying to park near Berkeley's Greek Theatre, loves Led Zeppelin's acoustic "Bron-Yr-Aur," and let out a laugh when he heard his grandmother had died. It's important that we know this.

It's important that we lear...

item.title: Angel Olsen's Roots Rock Prizes Feeling Over Certainty
item.description: Certainties are not easily extracted from Angel Olsen. She does not pluck them from the air like floating candies, nor does she rattle them off in conversation, nor do they routinely bubble up in her songs. If present at all, they're treated with cautious distance; they are meant to be skulked pa...

item.title: These Wounds Are Real, Man
item.description: Authenticity is a strange quality to praise in a punk band. Is there a more or less genuine way for vocalists to debase themselves on stage? Not really. Still, some seek to assess the earnestness of live antics, as if singers who split open their foreheads with microphones could be more or less "...

item.title: The Writing on the Wall: It's Graffiti Versus Murals in San Francisco and Oakland. Either Way, Street Artists Win.
item.description: Oscar Davalos began tagging when he was 12 years old. He and his friends would sneak out at night armed with cans of spray paint, scrawling their names on walls throughout East Oakland. The attraction was twofold: It was illegal, and it was art. Growing up in Fruitvale, Davalos dealt with the har...

item.title: Liquid Assets: While California Dries Up, San Francisco Stays Wet
item.description:
The year 2014 is shaping up to be one of California's driest since humans saw fit to commence measuring such things. San Francisco, however, is a town that's loath to dry out. We continue to power-wash filth off our streets and flush our toilets with pre-drought abandon.

What's more, we d...

item.title: All Rise: The Lawsuit Challenging Waterfront Height Limits Reaches Strange Heights of Its Own
item.description: Big-time land use and litigation go together like daytime baseball and hot dogs. So, it's little surprise that a lawsuit underwritten by the San Francisco Giants — a baseball franchise and aspiring waterfront high-rise developer — is aiming to knock a measure off the forthcoming June ...

item.title: Arthouse Movie Listings February 26-March 4, 2014
item.description: Artists' Television Access. Lemon: Documentary about Tony Award-winning street poet Lemon Andersen, whose troubled life has fueled his art even as it kept him mired in the projects. Wed., Feb. 26, 7 p.m. $10-$12. Adjectives in the Halting Speech: Films by Jonathan Schwartz: 16mm exp...

item.title: The Roar of the Void: Fans Revel in a Tour of an Empty Stadium
item.description:
Anyone who's ever shown up for a home game when the team is on the road has been forced to search for silver linings. It's not easy. Parking is a breeze, though. Huh — there's one!

Legions of San Franciscans, however, still flock to Candlestick Park, where the next opponent figures ...

item.title: Accounts Still Denied: Banks Won't Touch Pot
item.description:
A great way to be treated like a criminal is to act like one. And one way to act suspiciously is to deal entirely in cash — large amounts of it, for all of your daily transactions.

So if marijuana is a billion-dollar industry in California, like they say, it's a billion dollars in c...

item.title: #Takingupspace: A Queer Dance Party Changes Its Tune by Asking Straights to Stay Away
item.description:
On Feb. 15, Oakland-based queer dance party, Ships in the Night, posted this on its Facebook page:

"if you are *cis* straight & thinking of coming to Ships In The Night, please consider that you are taking the place of a queer person. #realtalk #takingupspace"

And right below that...

item.title: The Old Factory System: San Francisco Fills the Air with Miasmas of Past, Present, and Future
item.description: You are able to read these words thanks to four different sorts of cells within your eyes called "receptors," which convert light into electrochemical impulses. You are able to feel the paper, the keyboard, the touchpad, the dude rubbing up against you on the bus thanks to, literally, just a hand...

item.title: The Snatch: Foul News on Every Street
item.description:
Bad Taste

Police are warning San Francisco pet owners to keep an eye out after police found nearly two dozen poisonous meatballs over the weekend, the same kind that killed a dog last summer. San Francisco Animal Control officers spent about four hours Saturday morning scouring a T...

item.title: SF Weekly Letters February 26-March 4, 2014
item.description:
A Failing Grade

Reader points out it's not the teachers' fault: And that is why the public must honor these pensions ["Money for Nothing," News, Joe Eskenazi, 2/19]. It is not the average teachers' fault that these cretins of capitalism stole money. It saddens me that people...

item.title: Filler App: How Tech Companies Are Disrupting Restaurant Delivery
item.description: Like most busy San Franciscans, I eat a lot of takeout, and also complain heartily about the lack of delivery options in the city. (Along with taxis and late-night dining, takeout is an area where New York has us handily beat.) Popular New York apps like Seamless and GrubHub aren't very useful he...

item.title: Los Shucos: Gut-Busting Hot Dogs in the Mission
item.description: Whether or not hot dogs turn out to be the next It thing to get (re)discovered, everyone should make haste to the Mission to try one at Los Shucos. After becoming hugely popular in Guatemala after hot dogs first became a thing there decades ago, the quintessential American food has now boomerange...

item.title: Cerveceria de MateVeza Expands to Polk Gulch
item.description: Even smaller than Cerveceria de MateVeza's original space — in an absolutely killer location at Dolores Park's northwest corner — comes another beer-and-empanadas offering from the same team, Woods Polk Station. The Marina/Polk Gulch frontier is a neighborhood lined with purveyors of ...

item.title: Virgil's Sea Room: The Discreet Charm of the Creative Class
item.description:
"I came to San Francisco because I was interested in art and politics," Jeremy says.

We're sitting in comfy chairs in Virgil's Sea Room, in the Mission. I'm sipping on a whiskey and ginger beer drink named after Warren Hellman. "Do you think anyone comes here for art and politics anymore?...

item.title: SF Weekly Recent Openers February 26-March 4, 2014
item.description: Horner's Corner: Noe Valley's latest bistro (in the space formerly known as Noe's Bar) has a New American menu that prominently features pizzas from its brick oven. It's also offering brunch right out of the gate, and its activity-filled kids menu illustrates the place's family-friendly vi...
